title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason Denis Diderot was locked up in a dungeon outside Paris in 1749?

options.label: A
options.text: For writing an essay about a philosopher's deathbed rejection of God.

options.label: B
options.text: For translating a book from English to French.

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote much of the music section in the cyclopedia in three months?

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the difference in skin color among people?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of melanin in their skin.

options.label: B
options.text: The type of skin cells they have.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of sunlight they are exposed to.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of melanin in the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the skin from damage caused by UV light.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce vitamin D in the skin.

options.label: C
options.text: To give the skin its color.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the skin absorb minerals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the pigment that gives skin and hair its color?
What is the result of exposure to UV light for long periods of time?
What is the name of the deadly cancer that forms in the skin's melanocytes?
What is the key to survival for humans exposed to UV light?
What happens when skin is exposed to UV light?

options.label: C
options.text: The skin starts to produce melanin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of UV light for the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to produce vitamin D.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to protect the skin from damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a vitamin D deficiency in humans?
What is the reason for the variation in skin color among humans?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of melanin in their skin.

options.label: B
options.text: The type of skin cells they have.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of sunlight they are exposed to.

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: What is considered the most powerful sound in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Speaking ill of someone who is present

options.label: B
options.text: Speaking well of someone who is absent

options.label: C
options.text: Speaking ill of someone who is not present

options.label: D
options.text: To speak with a loud or boisterous voice

options.label: A
options.text: Deep breathing, lip trills, tongue trills, rolling Rs, and humming

options.label: B
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, sigh out, Ba, Ba, Ba, brrrrrr, la, la, la, and Rrrrr

options.label: C
options.text: Weeeaawww, deep breathing, lip trills, tongue trills, and rolling Rs

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is unnecessary for effective communication

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: What is the topic that Joseph Geni says is rarely discussed in education reform?

options.label: B
options.text: The value and importance of human connection.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The role of standardized testing in education.

multiple-choice.question: According to James Comer, what is necessary for significant learning to occur?

What did the teacher, Ms. Pierson, do when she realized she had taught the lesson wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: She ignored the mistake and continued with the lesson.

options.label: B
options.text: She apologized to the students and explained the correct information.

options.label: C
options.text: She blamed the students for not paying attention.

multiple-choice.question: What was the phrase that Ms. Pierson gave to her students to repeat?

options.label: A
options.text: "I am nobody. I was nobody when I came. I'll be a nobody when I leave."

options.label: B
options.text: "I am somebody. I was somebody when I came. I'll be a better somebody when I leave."

options.label: C
options.text: "I am powerful, and I am strong. I deserve the education that I get here."

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: She gave him a zero and told him to try harder.

options.label: D
options.text: She gave him a pass and told him to ignore the mistakes.

options.label: A
options.text: She gave them extra homework and chores.

options.label: B
options.text: She bought them combs and brushes and peanut butter and crackers to put in her desk drawer.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the legacy that Ms. Walker left behind?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A legacy of technology and innovation.

options.label: D
options.text: A legacy of standardized testing and evaluation.

options.text: It's a tough job that requires patience and understanding.

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is HeLa?

options.label: C
options.text: A line of human cells that can divide indefinitely.

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered the first immortal line of human cells?
What was special about the tumor that Henrietta Lacks had?

options.label: C
options.text: It produced an endless source of identical cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is apoptosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A process that prevents the propagation of genetic errors.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of sending HeLa cells to labs all over the world?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: To build careers and fortunes off of Henrietta's cells.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of using HeLa cells to test the polio vaccine?

options.label: D
options.text: The vaccine was still in development.

multiple-choice.question: What is telomerase?

options.label: A
options.text: An enzyme that helps cancer cells evade destruction.

multiple-choice.question: What was discovered in HeLa cells that helped us understand cervical cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only travel on lab surfaces.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only travel on human skin.

options.label: C
options.text: They can travel on almost any surface and take over like weeds.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only travel on a specific type of surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of HeLa cells on scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: They have led to the discovery of thousands of scientific papers.

options.label: B
options.text: They have led to the development of new vaccines.

options.label: C
options.text: They have led to the discovery of a cure for cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: They have led to the understanding of how diseases develop.

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main concern about the way math is taught in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: That students are not learning enough math concepts.

options.label: B
options.text: That students are not retaining math reasoning skills.

options.label: C
options.text: That students are not enjoying math class.

options.label: D
options.text: That teachers are not being paid enough.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the way math textbooks are written?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too hard for students to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They do not provide enough examples.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not involve students in the formulation of the problem.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to teaching math?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide students with all the answers and solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: To have students work on problems in isolation.

options.label: C
options.text: To involve students in the formulation of the problem and encourage patient problem-solving.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on memorization of formulas.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think it is an amazing time to be a math teacher?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the availability of new technology.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the increased funding for math education.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the availability of free and open-source educational resources.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the decrease in student interest in math.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to using multimedia in the classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: To use it to provide students with all the answers and solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: To use it to have students work on problems in isolation.

options.label: C
options.text: To use it to bring the real world into the classroom and encourage student intuition.

options.label: D
options.text: To use it to focus on memorization of formulas.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think it is important to be less helpful to students?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it makes it easier for teachers to grade their work.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes it easier for students to cheat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it encourages patient problem-solving and math reasoning.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it makes it easier for teachers to provide answers and solutions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for his students?

options.label: A
options.text: To have them memorize formulas and solve problems quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: To have them develop patient problem-solving skills and math reasoning.

options.label: C
options.text: To have them enjoy math class and learn new concepts.

options.label: D
options.text: To have them become math experts and compete in math competitions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to using video in the classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: To use it to provide students with all the answers and solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: To use it to have students work on problems in isolation.

options.label: C
options.text: To use it to bring the real world into the classroom and encourage student intuition.

options.label: D
options.text: To use it to focus on memorization of formulas.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think it is important to involve students in the formulation of the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it makes it easier for teachers to grade their work.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes it easier for students to cheat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it encourages patient problem-solving and math reasoning.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it makes it easier for teachers to provide answers and solutions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message to his audience?

options.label: A
options.text: That math is a difficult subject and should be avoided.

options.label: B
options.text: That math is a necessary subject and should be learned.

options.label: C
options.text: That math can be made more accessible and enjoyable through patient problem-solving and math reasoning.

options.label: D
options.text: That math is a subject that should be taught in isolation.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: You can safely trust the majority in both trios.

options.label: B
options.text: You can safely ignore the duo.

options.label: C
options.text: You can figure out the fourth path using the majority's report.

options.label: D
options.text: You can safely trust the pair.

options.label: D
options.text: You can safely ignore the duo.

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

options.label: D
options.text: All its internal organs are identical.

multiple-choice.question: What is a condition where all internal organs are flipped?
What is a small pit on the embryo that is thought to contribute to asymmetry?
What is a characteristic of the cilia on the node of an embryo?

options.label: A
options.text: They are lined with tiny hairs.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not lined with tiny hairs.

options.label: C
options.text: They are lined with large hairs.

options.label: D
options.text: They are lined with no hairs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the direction of the fluid flow caused by the synchronized rotation of the cilia on the node?

options.label: A
options.text: From the left side of the embryo to the right.

options.label: B
options.text: From the right side of the embryo to the left.

options.label: C
options.text: From the top of the embryo to the bottom.

options.label: D
options.text: From the bottom of the embryo to the top.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first organ to show asymmetry in the developing embryo?
What is a characteristic of proteins that control cell migration and embryonic cilia twirl?
What is a property of biomolecules that is reflected in asymmetric cells, embryos, and organisms?
What is the term for the property of a molecule and its mirror image not being identical?

title: When will the next mass extinction occur? - Borths, D'Emic, and Pritchard

multiple-choice.question: What is a mass extinction event?

options.label: A
options.text: A rare occurrence where entire species are wiped out as a result of activity by better adapted organisms.

options.label: B
options.text: A sudden disappearance of lineages that persisted through several geological layers.

options.label: C
options.text: A massive change in the environment that occurs too quickly for most living creatures to adapt, causing thousands of species to die off in a geological instant.

options.label: D
options.text: A gradual decline of species over a long period of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the largest mass extinction event in Earth's history?

options.label: B
options.text: The extinction of 95% of species in the ocean and on land between the Permian and Triassic periods.

options.label: C
options.text: The fluctuation of massive ice sheets at our planet's poles over the last few million years.

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of a certain hominid species originating in Africa 150,000 years ago.

multiple-choice.question: What was happening to the Earth's land masses 252 million years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: They were breaking apart and moving away from each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They were gathering together into the single supercontinent Pangaea.

options.label: C
options.text: They were being filled with oceans and shallow tropical seas.

options.label: D
options.text: They were being affected by massive volcanic eruptions.

multiple-choice.question: What is causing the extinction of species today?

options.label: A
options.text: The fluctuation of massive ice sheets at our planet's poles.

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of a certain hominid species originating in Africa 150,000 years ago.

options.label: C
options.text: The changing environments and ecosystems due to human activity.

options.label: D
options.text: The normal occurrence of extinction in the background of ecosystems.

multiple-choice.question: What can humans do to prevent mass extinctions?

options.label: A
options.text: By learning about past extinction events and recognizing what is happening today as environments change.

options.label: B
options.text: By using their unique ability to drive mass extinctions to make the world a more destructive place.

options.label: C
options.text: By lessening their effect on other species and using their knowledge to transform humanity's impact on the world.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the problem and continuing to drive mass extinctions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the single supercontinent that existed 252 million years ago?
What is the name of the strange reptiles of the Permian period?
What is the name of the hominid species that originated in Africa 150,000 years ago?
What is the name of the event that occurred 66 million years ago?
What is the rate of extinction today compared to the normal background?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the same as the normal background.

options.label: B
options.text: It is higher than the normal background.

options.label: C
options.text: It is hundreds to thousands of times higher than the normal background.

options.label: D
options.text: It is lower than the normal background.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: A farming technique that increases crops.

options.label: B
options.text: A shelter built from branches, leaves, and grass.

options.label: C
options.text: A shelter built from mud bricks and clay.

options.label: D
